I enjoy the explanations, but as for science nomenclature, I think a few things need to be revamped...

For example, "hydrogen bonds" when there isn't hydrogen present.

And "Oxidizer", when there isn't oxygen present.

These terms are not clarity, they are confusing. If the properties are around electron donation or affinity, then just label it as such.
It isn't "angstrom," "ang'-struhm." It's Ångström, i.e., "OHNG-stroohm." It's Swedish. It's not rocket science.

A cautionary tale to those chanting the "follow the science" mantra. Scientific discovery is often messy and rarely proceeds in a straight line. We should follow the science, but with a good dose of humility.

Hydrogen bonding but with carbon. But actually not with carbon. With oxygen and hydrogen. This video is a complete misunderstanding of everything it talks about. There's nothing about carbon-hydrogen bonding. Its only about intramolectular hydrogen bonding which is still between something electronegative (oxygen) and electropositive (hydrogen), its just mediated by an aromatic ring that happens to contain carbon. Maybe next time don't just copy "C-H⋯O" from wikipedia and actually read the article.

Interesting.
This is a question for any fellow Chemistry enthusiasts/students/teachers: Could this be because the N bonded to the C pulls more of the electrons towards the N? This leaves the C with a delta positive charge. This then induces a slight positive charge on the H to which that C is bonded to. Thus, H has a greater attraction to nearby O, which is delta negatively charged. Somewhat similar to having electron withdrawing groups in a molecule.
Also, something to question/but I may be wrong: the C is bonded to a N of an amide. Due to amides resonance structure, we can say the O of the amide is electron withdrawing, and thus results in the delta positive N of the amide. This then pulls more electron density from the C, which then does to the H "2 bonds away". Thus, the H on that C bonded to the amide (aka. peptide bond in proteins) is not like a H on a pure hydrocarbon, like an alkane, etc.
Maybe we have to consider the effect of an electronegative atom/electron-withdrawing group that may not be directly bonded to the H, but 2 or even 3 bonds away (especially in a resonance system with delocalised pi electrons). Just like how the chemical shift (ppm) of the H in 1H-NMR, is effected by atoms 2 or 3 bonds away? But I may be wrong as the inductive effect drops significantly past one bond.

Anyway, thanks for reading my thoughts - I may be completely wrong though, but as a student myself, I love chemistry!

The fun (read: awful) thing about x-ray crystallography is that the diffraction pattern itself only gives 2 of the 3 components of the light wave (frequency and amplitude) needed to figure out the 3D structure of the protein. The last one, phase, is pretty much a crapshoot of making educated guesses about how the model should look and seeing how it compares to the raw data you have.

To the physicists, structural biologists, and chemists who really understand how a Fourier transform works, you are truly built different and I am absolutely terrified of you.

4:30 - Yes, Rosalind did the x-ray crystallography. I do not believe that stating Watson & Crick stole it is accurate.

In 1951, a scientist named Maurice Wilkins working at Kings College
laboratory heard about Franklin’s expertise with X-ray crystallography
and sought her out to join his research team. She was hired and produced the x-ray photograph that Wilkins later shared with Watson and Crick. It was not "stolen" - not crediting her in their research is low... but not "stealing" , i.e. any more than not citing the name of a lab-tech that does routine isolations in blood plasma that turns up a new species of blood born-parasite where the researchers that ordered the work be done were the only ones cited. Big whoop - it's only important if your motivations are divisive in nature.
